Wherever you're going, a benefit of the F-1 or J-1 status is the ability to reenter the U.S. following travel. On this page, you'll find everything you need to know on traveling and reentering the U.S. on F-1 or J-1 status. Make sure to review the Basic Process section, especially Documents to Carry which tells you what you need to bring when you travel. If you're going to Canada, Mexico or the Carribbean, check out our special circumstances section below. We want your travels to be as safe and smooth as possible.       Bon voyage!            Basic Process                                    Documents to Carry   What to bring when you travel internationally.                                                          How to get a travel signature     In NYC and outside of the U.S.                                       How to get a new visa   When your visa has expired and you're on OPT or Academic Training.         Special Circumstances                                        Canada, Mexico or the Caribbean   Special exceptions for F-1 or J-1 students and scholars.                                   Post Completion Travel     Everything you need to know for traveling while on OPT or Academic Training.                                     Traveling with an I-515A   Read this section if you have an I-515A and need to leave again within 30 days. Register       Book NYU travel on your own? You must register or update your itinerary with NYU's traveler safety service.                                    Amex         AMEX Travel       +1-888-477-0451             or              Egencia             An Expedia Company        +1-877-613-4284                                        New        Provide new travel information                    or               Update        Provide updates to existing itineraries                                                     NYU Traveler was created to provide the NYU community with tools and services for their travel needs and to help keep them safer. University-related travel may now be booked or registered through NYU Traveler.   From this site, you can use your NYU NetID and password to book on-line reservations for air, rail, hotel, or car with either Egencia (an Expedia company) or American Express Travel, or you can call an agent at Egencia or AMEX Travel via the telephone numbers provided. By using one of these agencies, your travel plans will be automatically connected to Worldcue, a traveler safety service NYU has enlisted to provide you with up-to-the-minute information of potential threats to your safety during your travels, and to enable the University to get in touch with you to render aid in the event of an emergency.   Choice was an important precept for us in designing this system. You can elect to make your NYU-related travel arrangements through other means and then register your travel itinerary with Worldcue.                                  EMERGENCIES   NYU Public Safety: +1 212-998-2222  Consult your Worldcue Trip confirmation e-mail for local emergency authority contacts. Visit our "Discounts" Page and scroll to "Chauffeur Service." Read More          Need Help?     Send e-mail to nyutraveler.info@nyu.edu if you need any travel-related support. If you are an F-1 student, you are given a 60-day grace period after completing your degree, and if you are J-1 student you are given a 30-day grace period. This period of time is meant for you to make plans to leave the U.S. You can travel within the U.S., but if you leave and reenter, you may not return as an F-1 or J-1 student. Speak to an OGS advisor if you have further questions.          Travel while on OPT or Academic Training                                      Documents to Carry while on OPT   What to bring when you travel internationally while on OPT or Academic Training.                                                          How to get a new visa while on OPT   When your visa has expired and you're on OPT or Academic Training.           Related Topics                                      How to get a travel signature     Getting a travel signature is the same as before but with a shorter timeframe for a valid signature.                                         Canada, Mexico or the Caribbean   Special exceptions for F-1 or J-1 students and scholars.
